document_title: Evaluating Ocular Response in the Retina and Optic Nerve Head after Single and Fractionated High-Energy Protons
summary_full: This study investigated the effects of whole-body high-energy proton irradiation on mouse retinas and optic nerve heads (ONH), comparing single and fractionated doses. Mice received either a single 0.5 Gy dose or 12 fractions totaling 0.5 Gy over 25 days. Four months post-irradiation, significant increases in apoptotic cells were observed in both retina and ONH for both exposure types, with more pronounced changes in the ONH for fractionated doses. Oxidative stress, indicated by 4-hydroxynonenal (4-HNE) immunoreactivity, was elevated in both regions, with a single dose showing more pronounced effects in the retina and ONH. Blood-retina barrier (BRB) integrity was assessed using biomarkers AQP-4, ZO-1, and PECAM-1. The retina showed increased AQP-4 and PECAM-1 expression and decreased ZO-1 expression, indicating BRB disruption, particularly after a single dose. The ONH region exhibited limited AQP-4 and ZO-1 immunoreactivity, suggesting different BRB properties compared to the retina. The findings suggest that proton radiation induces oxidative stress-associated apoptosis and BRB changes in the retina, with differential responses between single and fractionated doses and distinct regional characteristics between the retina and ONH.
key_findings: Proton radiation (0.5 Gy) significantly increases apoptosis in mouse retinas and optic nerve heads (ONH) four months post-exposure, regardless of single or fractionated dosing.
Oxidative stress, measured by 4-HNE, is elevated in both retina and ONH after proton irradiation, with a single dose showing more pronounced effects.
Blood-retina barrier (BRB) integrity is disrupted in the retina, evidenced by increased AQP-4 and PECAM-1 expression and decreased ZO-1 expression.
The ONH region shows limited expression of BRB biomarkers (AQP-4, ZO-1), suggesting different barrier properties compared to the retina.
Cellular responses in the retina and ONH to radiation insults may be differentially regulated by acute versus hyperfractionated dose schedules.
future_research_fields: Investigating the mechanisms behind differential radiation responses in the retina versus the ONH.
Exploring countermeasures for space radiation-induced ocular damage.
Further studies on vascular permeability and clearance mechanisms in the ONH.
Utilizing a systems biology approach to link ophthalmic changes with other organ pathologies post-radiation.

conclusions: Exposure to 0.5 Gy of proton radiation induces oxidative stress-associated apoptosis in the mouse retina and ONH and alters BRB integrity in the retina. The study highlights differences in BRB biomarker distribution between the retina and ONH, and suggests that cellular responses to radiation may be differentially regulated by acute versus fractionated dose schedules.
impact_statement: This research provides crucial insights into the ocular risks of space radiation, informing strategies to protect astronaut vision during long-duration space missions.
